trial_identification.scientifictitle: Evaluation of the safety and efficacy of selenium-coated contact lenses

interventions.interventions: Comparison of performance of selenium-coated contact lenses to that of high oxygen permeable lenses when worn on a monthly replacement daily or continuous wear schedule for up to 6 months. Subjects will wear the test selenium lens in one eye and the control marketed lens in the other eye

primaryOutcome.outcome: To determine whether selenium coated lenses are safe and effective for daily and extended wear. The trial will last for up to 6 months.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Assessments will occur on a monthly basis

secondaryOutcome.outcome: To determine whether selenium coated lenses retain antibacterial efficacy after wear.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Lenses will be assessed on after each month of wear.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Be able to read, comprehend and give informed consent as demonstrated by signing a record of informed consent. be willing to comply with the lens wearing and clinical trial visit schedule as directed by the Investigator. have ocular health findings considered to be normal and which would not prevent the subject from safely wearing contact lenses. have vision correctable to at least 20/40 or better in each eye with spherical contact lenses.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Contraindications to hydrogel contact lens wear. any systemic or ocular disease or active condition or use of medications that may affect the eye or be exacerbated by wearing contact lenses. pre-existing ocular irritation that would preclude contact lens fitting. undergone eye surgery in the 12 weeks immediately prior to enrolment for the trial. undergone corneal refractive surgery.

trial_design.designfeatures: Test lens in one eye, control lens in the other eye

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Rupert Myers Building, University of New South Wales, Sydney, NSW

fundingsource.fundingaddress: Rupert Myers Building, University of New South Wales, Sydney, NSW

ethicsAndSummary.summary: To determine whether contact lenses containing selenium can be worn safely and prevent bacterial colonisation of their surface. Both the dispensing optometrists and contact lens wearers will be masked.

contact.name: Professor Mark Willcox
contact.address: Institute for Eye Research Rupert Myers Building University of New South Wales Sydney NSW 2056
